title: Delivery Food Safety
legalBasis: Royal Decree 3484/2000 on hygiene standards for food preparation and delivery; EU Regulation (EC) No 852/2004, Annex II, Chapter IX on temperature control during transport; Royal Decree 640/2006 on HACCP implementation for food delivery operations
summary:
Food delivery has become an increasingly important part of hospitality operations, accelerated by online platforms and changing consumer expectations. However, delivery presents unique food safety challenges. Once food leaves the establishment, it enters an uncontrolled environment where temperature abuse, physical damage, and contamination can occur. The food business operator remains legally responsible for food safety throughout the delivery process until the food reaches the customer.

EU Regulation 852/2004 requires that food must be protected against contamination during transport and that temperature control must be maintained throughout. For delivered foods, this means hot foods must arrive at the customer at 65°C or above (or must be consumed within 2 hours of preparation), cold foods must be delivered at 8°C or below, and all foods must be protected from physical contamination and damage during transport. The delivery timeframe is critical — the shorter the delivery time, the easier it is to maintain food safety standards.

Effective delivery food safety management requires appropriate packaging that maintains temperature and protects food integrity, insulated transport equipment adequate for the delivery duration and distance, route planning that minimizes delivery time, driver training on food safety and proper handling procedures, and customer communication about safe handling and consumption timeframes. With proper systems, food delivery can be safe and high quality. Without adequate controls, delivery operations pose serious food safety and reputational risks.
keyPoints: Hot foods must be delivered at 65°C or above, or consumed within 2 hours of leaving temperature control
Cold foods must be delivered at 8°C or below using insulated containers with ice packs or refrigeration
Delivery time should be minimized — ideally under 30 minutes for temperature-sensitive foods
Food must be packaged in sealed, tamper-evident containers that protect against contamination
Insulated delivery bags or containers appropriate for food temperature and delivery duration must be used
Delivery vehicles must be clean, maintained, and suitable for food transport
Delivery drivers must be trained in food safety, proper handling, and temperature maintenance
Temperature monitoring records should be maintained for high-risk delivery operations

sections.heading: 1. Legal Framework for Food Delivery
sections.content:
Food delivery operations are subject to the same food safety regulations as on-premises service, with additional requirements specific to transport. EU Regulation 852/2004, Annex II, Chapter IX addresses transport of foodstuffs: conveyances and containers used for transporting foodstuffs must be kept clean and maintained in good repair, receptacles in vehicles must not be used for transporting anything other than foodstuffs where this might result in contamination, and where necessary, conveyances and containers must be capable of maintaining appropriate temperature.

In Spain, Royal Decree 3484/2000 establishes that establishments providing takeaway or delivery services must ensure food maintains appropriate quality and safety standards throughout the delivery process. This includes temperature maintenance, protection from contamination, and delivery within timeframes that ensure food safety. Food business operators are responsible for food safety until the food is in the customer's control — this means liability extends through the delivery process.

The growth of third-party delivery platforms (Uber Eats, Deliveroo, Glovo, Just Eat) has created complexity regarding responsibility. While the delivery platform may handle logistics, the food business operator remains responsible for food safety. Contracts with delivery platforms should clearly specify requirements for insulated containers, delivery timeframes, driver training, and temperature monitoring. The restaurant cannot delegate its legal food safety responsibilities to the delivery platform.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Temperature Requirements During Delivery
subsections.content:
The fundamental temperature requirement is that food must be maintained outside the danger zone (5-63°C) during transport. Hot foods should be maintained at 65°C or above from dispatch to delivery. If this cannot be guaranteed (e.g., for deliveries exceeding 30 minutes in ambient conditions), an alternative framework applies: food may be allowed to cool during delivery provided it is delivered and consumed within 2 hours of leaving temperature control, during which bacterial growth is limited.

Cold foods must be maintained at 8°C or below (preferably 5°C or below) throughout delivery. This requires active cooling — insulated containers alone are insufficient for cold food delivery unless delivery time is very short (under 15 minutes). Ice packs, gel packs, or refrigerated transport are required for cold foods. The specific method depends on delivery duration, ambient temperature, and the type of cold food being delivered.

subsections.heading: 1.2 Packaging and Contamination Prevention
subsections.content:
Delivered food must be packaged to prevent contamination during transport. Packaging must be: food-safe and suitable for the food type and temperature, sealed or closeable to prevent contamination entry, sturdy enough to prevent physical damage during transport, and ideally tamper-evident so customers can verify food has not been accessed during delivery. Single-use packaging is typical for delivery operations as it ensures each order receives clean, uncontaminated packaging.

Separate packaging should be used for different food components: hot and cold items must be packaged separately to prevent temperature transfer, liquid items must be sealed to prevent spillage, and strong-smelling items should be separated from other foods. For allergen safety, allergen-free orders should be packaged distinctly and sealed to prevent cross-contamination during transport. Clear labeling of packages with contents, customer name, and any special handling instructions (e.g., 'keep upright', 'fragile') helps ensure proper handling.

subsections.heading: 1.3 Delivery Vehicle Requirements
subsections.content:
Vehicles used for food delivery must be suitable for the purpose, maintained in clean condition, and equipped appropriately for temperature maintenance. For own-fleet deliveries, the business should establish vehicle standards including regular cleaning schedules (particularly for vehicles also used for non-food purposes), maintenance programs ensuring vehicles are in good repair, insulated storage areas or containers for food, securing systems to prevent food shifting during transport, and separation of food from non-food items.

For third-party delivery services, contractual requirements should specify vehicle cleanliness standards, requirement for food-grade insulated bags or containers, prohibition of transporting non-food items in the same compartment as food, and regular vehicle inspection. While the delivery platform is responsible for vehicle standards, the food business should verify compliance through periodic checks and should refuse to use services that do not meet adequate standards.

sections.heading: 2. Packaging and Temperature Maintenance Systems
sections.content:
Effective packaging and temperature maintenance systems are the foundation of safe food delivery. Packaging must serve multiple functions: maintain food temperature, protect food from physical damage and contamination, present food attractively, and provide information to the customer. Temperature maintenance systems range from simple insulated bags suitable for short deliveries to sophisticated heated or refrigerated transport for long-distance or high-volume operations.

The investment in quality packaging and temperature maintenance equipment must be balanced against the volume and nature of the delivery operation. A restaurant with occasional delivery orders may manage with basic insulated bags and strict delivery time limits. A dedicated delivery or catering operation requires professional-grade equipment with proven temperature maintenance performance. Whatever the scale, the system must be validated to ensure it maintains required temperatures for the expected delivery duration.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Hot Food Packaging and Containers
subsections.content:
Hot food packaging must retain heat while allowing moisture escape to prevent sogginess. Common solutions include: insulated foam or cardboard containers with ventilation holes, aluminum containers with cardboard lids (excellent heat retention), compartmentalized containers separating different components, and specialized hot food bags or boxes with insulation and heat-reflective linings. Avoid fully sealed plastic containers for hot foods as condensation makes food soggy.

For transport, place hot food containers in insulated delivery bags designed for heat retention. High-quality bags have thick insulation (minimum 1cm foam), heat-reflective internal lining, and zippered or Velcro closures that seal completely. Some systems use heated delivery bags with battery-powered or vehicle-powered heating elements maintaining 65-70°C — these are suitable for longer deliveries or cold ambient conditions. Pre-warm insulated bags before use by placing a heat source inside (hot water bottles or heat packs) then removing it before adding food — this prevents the bag from absorbing heat from the food.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Cold Food Packaging and Cooling Systems
subsections.content:
Cold food packaging must maintain refrigeration temperatures throughout delivery. Options include: refrigerated gel packs or ice packs positioned around food containers, insulated bags or boxes with cooling capacity, phase change materials (PCMs) specifically designed for food transport, and refrigerated transport vehicles for high-volume or long-distance deliveries. The number and positioning of cooling elements must be sufficient for the delivery duration and ambient temperature.

For short deliveries (under 20 minutes) in moderate ambient temperatures, pre-chilled insulated bags with two gel packs (one on bottom, one on top of food) may suffice. For longer deliveries or hot weather, increase cooling capacity: more gel packs, larger bags with better insulation, or refrigerated containers. Pre-chill all cooling elements to -18°C (freezer temperature) before use. Pre-chill insulated bags in refrigerated storage before packing food. Monitor actual delivered temperatures periodically to verify that the cooling system is adequate.

subsections.heading: 2.3 Temperature Monitoring and Validation
subsections.content:
Validate that your packaging and temperature maintenance system actually maintains required temperatures over typical delivery durations. Conduct validation testing: pack food (or a temperature probe in a food simulant) as for actual delivery, transport for typical delivery duration in realistic conditions, and measure food temperature on arrival. Repeat testing under different conditions: short and long deliveries, hot and cold ambient temperatures, different food types.

For ongoing operations, implement periodic temperature monitoring. For high-risk or high-volume delivery operations, equip some delivery bags with temperature data loggers that record temperature throughout delivery. Review data to verify temperature maintenance and identify any system failures. For lower-volume operations, periodic spot-checks where a supervisor accompanies a delivery and measures food temperature on arrival can verify system performance. Document all validation testing and monitoring results.

sections.heading: 3. Operational Procedures and Time Management
sections.content:
Time is the critical variable in delivery food safety — the shorter the time between preparation and consumption, the lower the food safety risk and the better the food quality. Operational procedures should minimize the time food spends in transit while maintaining quality standards. This requires efficient production planning, strategic route planning and delivery zone management, systems that batch orders appropriately without excessive delays, and clear communication between kitchen, dispatch, and delivery staff.

Delay at any stage — food sitting waiting for a driver, driver waiting at restaurant for food, inefficient routing adding delivery time — increases food safety risk. Process efficiency in delivery operations is not just about customer satisfaction (though faster delivery does improve satisfaction); it is a food safety imperative. Every minute food spends in delivery is a minute closer to the time or temperature limits beyond which food becomes unsafe.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Preparation and Dispatch Timing
subsections.content:
Coordinate food preparation timing with driver availability to minimize waiting time. In an ideal system, food preparation completes just as the driver arrives to collect it, so food goes immediately from kitchen to insulated transport. This requires communication systems: digital platforms can coordinate timing automatically; manual operations require discipline in estimating preparation time and ensuring drivers are ready.

Do not prepare food far in advance of dispatch — this extends the total time between preparation and consumption. If unavoidable delays occur (driver unavailable, multiple simultaneous orders), hold prepared food under proper temperature control (hot food in hot holding at ≥65°C, cold food in refrigeration at ≤5°C) rather than packaged and waiting at ambient temperature. Mark all prepared delivery orders with preparation time so that orders exceeding safe waiting time can be identified and remade if necessary.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Delivery Zone and Route Management
subsections.content:
Define realistic delivery zones based on the time required to maintain food safety. For businesses using basic insulated containers without active heating/cooling, delivery zones might be limited to 15-20 minutes travel time. For operations with heated/refrigerated transport, zones can be larger. Be realistic about travel times during peak traffic periods — a delivery that takes 15 minutes off-peak may take 40 minutes during rush hour.

Implement route optimization to minimize delivery time. For multiple-order delivery runs, plan routes that minimize total travel time while ensuring that no individual order exceeds safe delivery time. Some orders may need dedicated delivery rather than being combined with other orders if the combined route would be too long. Digital routing tools can optimize delivery efficiency, but human judgment is needed to ensure food safety limits are not exceeded for operational efficiency.

subsections.heading: 3.3 Delivery Time Limits and Monitoring
subsections.content:
Establish maximum delivery time limits based on your temperature maintenance capabilities and validation testing. A common framework is: maximum 30 minutes for hot foods in standard insulated bags, maximum 45 minutes for hot foods in heated transport, maximum 30 minutes for cold foods with gel pack cooling, and maximum 90 minutes for cold foods in refrigerated transport. These are examples — your specific limits should be based on validation testing of your actual systems.

Monitor actual delivery times and investigate any that exceed targets. Track dispatch time (when food leaves the kitchen) and delivery time (when customer receives food), calculating total delivery duration. Analyze data to identify patterns: routes that consistently exceed time limits, peak periods where volume creates delays, or drivers who are consistently slower than others. Use data to optimize operations: adjust delivery zones, modify peak-hour procedures, provide additional driver training, or invest in better temperature maintenance equipment.

sections.heading: 4. Driver Training and Hygiene
sections.content:
Delivery drivers are food handlers and must meet the same hygiene standards and training requirements as kitchen and service staff. Drivers handle food packages, interact with customers, and are responsible for maintaining food safety during transport. Royal Decree 109/2010 requires all food handlers, including delivery drivers, to receive appropriate food hygiene training.

Driver training should cover: legal requirements and food business responsibility for food safety during delivery, temperature maintenance importance and how to use insulated containers and cooling/heating systems correctly, time limits and why minimizing delivery time is critical, hygiene standards including hand washing and personal cleanliness, proper handling of food packages to prevent damage and contamination, what to do if accidents or spills occur during delivery, and customer interaction including communicating safe handling instructions. Documented training and assessment of competence should be maintained for all drivers.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Personal Hygiene for Drivers
subsections.content:
Delivery drivers must maintain appropriate personal hygiene standards. Before starting their shift, drivers should wash hands thoroughly and maintain clean clothing. While full food handler uniforms may not be necessary for drivers, clothing should be clean and appropriate. Drivers who also perform other roles in the restaurant (e.g., drivers who also work as servers or kitchen assistants) must follow full food handler hygiene standards including work clothing and hair restraints.

Drivers must wash hands: before starting work, after using the toilet, after handling waste or dirty equipment, and before handling food packages. Hand sanitizer should be available in delivery vehicles for use when handwashing facilities are not accessible. Drivers experiencing symptoms of foodborne illness (vomiting, diarrhea, fever) must not work and must report symptoms to management. Drivers with cuts or wounds on hands should cover them with blue waterproof plasters and wear disposable gloves when handling food packages.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Vehicle Hygiene and Maintenance
subsections.content:
Delivery vehicles must be kept clean and in good repair. For dedicated delivery vehicles or motorcycles, establish cleaning schedules: daily cleaning of food storage areas, weekly deep cleaning of entire vehicle, and immediate cleaning if spillages occur. The vehicle interior where food is carried should be free from dirt, debris, and contaminants. Food should never be transported in vehicle trunks or areas also used for non-food items that might contaminate food.

For driver-owned vehicles used for delivery, establish minimum cleanliness standards and conduct periodic inspections. Drivers should be required to demonstrate that their vehicle is clean and suitable before being approved for delivery work. Insulated delivery bags should never be placed on vehicle floors — use seats, passenger areas, or dedicated racks. After deliveries, remove all delivery packaging and waste from vehicles. Any spillages or contamination in the vehicle must be cleaned immediately and the vehicle should not be used for food delivery until cleaning is complete.

subsections.heading: 4.3 Handling Procedures and Customer Interaction
subsections.content:
Train drivers in proper food handling procedures: how to load food into insulated containers without contamination, how to secure food in vehicles to prevent shifting or damage during transport, how to carry and deliver food to customers without dropping or damaging packages, and what to do if food is dropped or damaged during delivery. Drivers should be instructed never to open food packages during delivery and to maintain the integrity of tamper-evident seals.

Customer interaction should include basic food safety communication. Drivers should inform customers if an order includes temperature-sensitive foods that should be consumed promptly. For larger orders or catering deliveries, drivers might communicate safe holding times: 'These hot items should be consumed within 2 hours for food safety.' Drivers should be trained to handle customer complaints or concerns professionally and to report food safety concerns (such as customer reporting illness) to management immediately.

sections.heading: 5. Special Considerations for Different Food Types
sections.content:
Different categories of delivered foods present different food safety challenges and require adapted procedures. High-risk cold foods (seafood, dairy-based items, cold meats, salads with mayonnaise) require rigorous temperature control and short delivery times. Hot foods with high moisture content cool more quickly than dry hot foods. Fried foods present quality challenges as crispness deteriorates rapidly. Understanding these differences enables appropriate risk management for each food type.

Some foods are inherently unsuitable for delivery given their temperature sensitivity or quality degradation characteristics. Food businesses should honestly assess whether particular menu items can be safely and satisfactorily delivered, or whether they should be restricted to on-premises service only. Offering delivery of unsuitable items risks both food safety incidents and customer dissatisfaction from poor quality. Better to have a limited delivery menu of items that travel well than a comprehensive menu where quality and safety cannot be guaranteed.

subsections.heading: 5.1 High-Risk Foods for Delivery
subsections.content:
High-risk foods that require careful management in delivery operations include: raw or lightly cooked foods (sushi, sashimi, steak tartare, rare burgers) which require continuous refrigeration ≤5°C and very short delivery times (maximum 20 minutes); dairy-based items (cream sauces, custards, cheesecakes) which are temperature-sensitive and support rapid bacterial growth if temperature-abused; seafood particularly shellfish and cold-prepared fish items requiring continuous cold chain; and mayonnaise-based salads and sandwiches which are high-risk if not maintained cold.

For these items, consider: restricting delivery to limited zones ensuring short delivery times, using enhanced cooling systems (more gel packs, refrigerated containers), implementing temperature monitoring for every delivery, providing customer instructions on immediate refrigeration upon receipt, or restricting these items to on-premises service only. Never compromise on safety — if adequate temperature control cannot be guaranteed for high-risk items during delivery, do not offer them for delivery.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Foods Requiring Modified Packaging
subsections.content:
Some foods require specialized packaging approaches for delivery. Fried foods (chips, tempura, fried chicken) benefit from ventilated containers that allow steam escape, preventing sogginess while retaining heat. Soups and sauces require completely sealed containers with secure lids, often double-packaged to prevent spillage. Layered items (burgers, sandwiches) may benefit from component separation, allowing customers to assemble on arrival to maintain quality.

Delicate items (cakes, desserts, sushi) require compartmentalized containers preventing movement and damage during transport. Beverages should be separated from foods to prevent condensation affecting food packaging. Pizza requires specialized boxes with internal support preventing lid contact with toppings. Ice cream and frozen desserts require insulated packaging with dry ice or gel packs maintaining freezing temperatures. Assess each menu item's packaging needs and test delivery performance before offering for delivery service.

subsections.heading: 5.3 Allergen Management in Delivery
subsections.content:
Allergen management in delivery operations requires additional controls beyond in-house service. Customers cannot ask serving staff about ingredients or preparation methods — they rely entirely on menu information and labeling. Ensure delivery menus include complete allergen information for all items using standardized formats. Online ordering platforms should have structured allergen information that customers can filter and search.

Package allergen-free orders separately and distinctly to prevent cross-contamination during transport, particularly if multiple orders are transported together. Use tamper-evident seals on allergen-free orders so customers can verify food has not been exposed to cross-contamination during delivery. Include allergen information on packaging labels. For customers with severe allergies, consider offering dedicated delivery (single order only) to eliminate cross-contamination risk. Never allow drivers to make ingredient substitutions without consulting the kitchen and the customer.

sections.heading: 6. HACCP and Documentation for Delivery Operations
sections.content:
Food delivery should be integrated into the establishment's HACCP plan. The hazard analysis should identify the specific risks associated with delivery: temperature abuse during transport, contamination during packaging and delivery, cross-contamination between orders during transport, and physical damage to food. Control measures should be documented including packaging specifications, temperature maintenance equipment and procedures, time limits for delivery, and driver training requirements.

Documentation should include: standard operating procedures for delivery food preparation, packaging, and dispatch; temperature monitoring records for delivered foods; delivery time records tracking dispatch and delivery times; validation testing results for temperature maintenance systems; driver training records; and incident reports for any food safety concerns during delivery. This documentation demonstrates compliance, enables process improvement, and provides evidence of due diligence if food safety incidents occur.

subsections.heading: 6.1 Critical Control Points in Delivery
subsections.content:
Depending on the hazard analysis, several points in the delivery process may be identified as Critical Control Points (CCPs). Temperature maintenance during delivery is often designated as a CCP with critical limits based on food type: hot foods ≥65°C on delivery or consumed within 2 hours of preparation, cold foods ≤8°C on delivery. Monitoring procedures might include periodic temperature checks of delivered foods, validation testing of temperature maintenance systems, and review of delivery time records.

Packaging integrity preventing contamination might be a CCP with the critical limit being that all food packages must be sealed and tamper-evident. Monitoring involves visual inspection before dispatch and customer feedback about packaging integrity. Delivery time might be a CCP with critical limits defined (e.g., maximum 30 minutes for standard deliveries). Monitoring involves tracking dispatch and delivery times through digital systems or driver reporting.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Monitoring and Record-Keeping
subsections.content:
Implement systems to monitor and document delivery operations. Digital ordering and dispatch systems automatically capture preparation time, dispatch time, and delivery time for every order. Manual systems require disciplined recording: a delivery log showing order number, customer, dispatch time, driver name, and delivery time. For high-risk operations, temperature monitoring records showing spot-check temperatures of delivered foods should be maintained.

Review monitoring records regularly to identify trends and issues. Calculate average delivery times overall and by driver, route, or time of day. Investigate deliveries exceeding time limits. If temperature spot-checks reveal non-compliances, investigate causes and implement corrective actions (improved insulated containers, modified delivery zones, additional driver training). Records should be retained for a reasonable period (typically 1-2 years minimum) and available for health inspection.

subsections.heading: 6.3 Continuous Improvement
subsections.content:
Use HACCP verification activities and monitoring data to drive continuous improvement in delivery operations. Analyze customer feedback for food safety or quality concerns related to delivery. Investigate any customer reports of temperature-abused food, packaging damage, or food safety concerns. Review monitoring data to identify areas for improvement: if many deliveries exceed time limits, consider adjusting delivery zones or increasing driver numbers during peak periods.

Periodically review and update delivery procedures: when introducing new menu items, validate they can be safely delivered; when delivery volume grows, assess whether current equipment and procedures remain adequate; when adopting new delivery platforms or services, verify they meet food safety requirements. Benchmark against industry best practices for delivery food safety. Invest in improved technology (better insulated containers, temperature monitoring systems, digital tracking) as delivery operations grow and justify investment.

checklists.title: Delivery Order Preparation and Dispatch Checklist
items: Food prepared just before driver arrival to minimize waiting time
Food packaged in appropriate temperature-maintenance containers
Hot and cold items packaged separately
All containers sealed and, where applicable, tamper-evident seals applied
Order labeled with customer name, address, and contents
Allergen information included if applicable
Special handling instructions noted (e.g., 'keep upright', 'contains allergens')
Food placed in appropriate insulated delivery bag (pre-warmed for hot, pre-chilled for cold)
Cooling elements (gel packs) added for cold food deliveries
Dispatch time recorded in delivery log or system
Driver instructed on delivery urgency for time-sensitive items

checklists.title: Delivery Driver Daily Checklist
items: Hands washed before starting shift
Clean clothing and appropriate personal hygiene maintained
Vehicle interior is clean and free from debris
Insulated delivery bags are clean and in good condition
Gel packs or cooling elements are fully frozen and ready for use
Hand sanitizer available in vehicle
Mobile phone or communication device functioning
Delivery addresses and route planned for efficiency
Food packages handled carefully to prevent damage during loading
Delivery completed within target time and delivery time recorded
Any customer feedback or concerns reported to management
Any spillages or damage during delivery reported and cleaned immediately

checklists.title: Weekly Delivery System Review
items: Review delivery time records — identify any exceeding limits
Analyze average delivery times by driver, route, and period
Review any customer complaints related to delivery food quality or safety
Check condition of insulated delivery bags and packaging supplies
Verify gel packs and cooling elements are adequate and in good condition
Verify all delivery drivers have current food safety training
Conduct spot-check of delivered food temperatures (periodic validation)
Review vehicle cleanliness standards with drivers
Update delivery procedures if issues identified
Document review and any corrective actions in HACCP verification records

bestPractices: Invest in high-quality insulated delivery bags designed for food transport — cheap bags do not maintain temperature adequately
Limit delivery zones to areas that can be reached within 20-30 minutes to maximize food safety and quality
Pre-warm (for hot) or pre-chill (for cold) insulated bags before packing food to maximize temperature maintenance
Use tamper-evident packaging for all delivery orders to build customer trust and enable detection of any interference during transport
Implement digital tracking systems that automatically record preparation, dispatch, and delivery times for all orders
Conduct regular temperature validation testing — actually measure delivered food temperatures to verify your system works
Consider offering a limited delivery menu focused on items that travel well rather than your complete on-premises menu
Partner with delivery platforms that demonstrate commitment to food safety through driver training, equipment standards, and time limits

glossary.Delivery Time: The period from when food leaves the restaurant (dispatch) until it reaches the customer (delivery), critical for food safety
glossary.Insulated Delivery Bag: Thermally insulated container designed to maintain food temperature during transport
glossary.Gel Pack: Sealed packet containing gel that can be frozen and used to maintain cold temperatures during food transport
glossary.Temperature Danger Zone: Temperature range (5-63°C) where pathogenic bacteria multiply most rapidly
glossary.Tamper-Evident Packaging: Packaging that shows visible evidence if it has been opened or interfered with, providing food security assurance
glossary.Third-Party Delivery Platform: Companies such as Uber Eats, Deliveroo, Glovo, or Just Eat that provide delivery logistics for restaurants
glossary.Validation Testing: Testing conducted to verify that temperature maintenance systems actually achieve required performance under realistic operating conditions
glossary.Phase Change Material (PCM): Substances that absorb or release thermal energy during phase transition (solid to liquid), used in some food transport cooling systems
glossary.Hot Holding: Maintaining hot cooked food at temperatures ≥65°C to prevent bacterial growth
glossary.Route Optimization: Planning delivery routes to minimize total travel time while ensuring each delivery is completed within safe time limits
